"What's wrong with me?" I thought to myself. "Why can't I just focus? Why do these thoughts keep creeping in?"

It hit me then - all this anxiety, it's just a symptom of the world's craziness. If everyone else could handle stress and uncertainty, why can't I?

Take my latest article, for instance. The editor wanted it done yesterday, but I knew I needed more time to get it right. So, I told them I'd have it by tomorrow instead. They freaked out on me, saying I was going to miss the deadline and that my clients would lose trust in me.

Sometimes I wonder if I'm just too sensitive, if I'm reading too much into things. But then I look around and see all the other anxious faces, all the stressed-out expressions, and I realize - we're all in this together.

My anxiety isn't something to be ashamed of; it's a sign of empathy, of compassion for the world's chaos. We need more people who feel deeply, who care enough to take action.

So, when people ask me how I manage my anxiety, I tell them it's simple: I just tune in to the world's frequency. I listen to its whispers, its fears, its doubts. And I respond accordingly.

It's not about avoiding reality; it's about embracing it head-on. My anxiety may be a reflection of the world's craziness, but it's also a reminder that we're all connected, that our emotions are intertwined like the threads of a tapestry.

When I'm feeling overwhelmed, I remind myself that it's okay to not be okay. That it's okay to feel scared, to feel uncertain. Because in doing so, I'm acknowledging the world's complexity, its messiness, and its beauty.

In the end, my anxiety isn't something to be cured; it's something to be celebrated. For it reminds us that we're human, that we're fragile, and that we're capable of feeling deeply.
